conbody.p: Most topics should be learningContent (information you present to the learner) or learningAssessment (quiz questions).

section.title: Learning module structure
section.p:
Each module should have a container topic, which provides the following:
A list of objectives for the module, using lcObjectives: <lcObjectives> <lcObjectivesGroup> <lcObjective>What kind of topics exist in DITA</lcObjective> <lcObjective>What information goes in different types of topics</lcObjective> <lcObjective>What are constraints and specialization?</lcObjective> </lcObjectivesGroup> </lcObjectives>
An estimated duration for the module, using lcDuration (provide a value in minutes):<lcDuration> <lcTime value="30"/> </lcDuration>
An overview of the module, using <lcIntro>
A list of additional reading resources, using <related-links>. Be sure to code external web links with the appropriate format (usually html or pdf) and scope (external):<link href="http://www.oxygenxml.com/dita/styleguide/webhelp-feedback/#Artefact/c_Syntax_and_Markup.html" format="html" scope="external"> <linktext>DITA Style Guide, Chapter 3, Syntax and Markup</linktext> </link>
Inside the overview container, provide learningContent topics with the module components (lessons).

section.title: Task structure
section.p: To create a task that directs a student to perform an exercise, use the learningContent topic type to introduce the material. If you need to provide introductory text to the exercise, you can add it to the <learningContentbody> element. The task itself should be a nested topic after the <learningContentbody> element. Below is a simplified example. For more, look in the course2 files.

section.title: Assessment structure
section.p: Assessments (test questions) come after the learning content in each module. In most cases you can use the shared file lcc_assessment.dita that introduces the questions in the LMS. If necessary (for example, if there are special instructions about the lesson's assessment), you can create an introduction topic of your own.

If you're using the shared introduction, create a <topicref> pointing to the file lcc_assessment.dita, then use the copy-to attribute to specify a filename (starting with lcc_assess_), that uniquely identifies the copy. Add a <navtitle> element that provides a lesson-specific title for the assessments introduction.

section.p: Each assessment question goes into its own learningAssessment topic. Itâ€™s a good idea to include title text in assessment topics; the title is not displayed to the reader in the LMS, but helps you locate the assessment in the LMS. Each assessment requires a unique ID for the question type (lcSingleSelect in the following sample). This is not the same as the ID of the learningAssessment topic itself.
section.codeblock: <learningAssessment id="assessment_htp_t21_wr"> <title></title> <prolog> <author>Sharon Burton</author> <author href="http://www.scriptorium.com">Sarah O'Keefe, Scriptorium</author> <critdates> <created date="2015-04-28"/> </critdates> </prolog> <learningAssessmentbody> <lcInteraction><lcSingleSelect id="topics3"> <lcQuestion>When creating a concept topic, you will often:</lcQuestion> <lcAnswerOptionGroup> ... </lcAnswerOptionGroup> </lcSingleSelect> </lcInteraction> </learningAssessmentbody> </learningAssessment>
section.p: Make sure you do not overlap with other IDs in the modules. Consider a unique ID prefix for your learning assessment content (for example, your initials or something related to the content you are developing).

p.note: The ditatraining project is being published to LearningDITA.com. LearningDITA.com runs on WordPress and LearnDashLMS. Currently, LearnDashLMS does not support feedback at the answer option level (lcAnswerOption/lcFeedback). However, LearnDashLMS does support correct and incorrect feedback at the question level, so rather than using lcFeedback, use lcFeedbackIncorrect.
